Modular arithmetic is a system of arithmetic for integers, where numbers "wrap around" when reaching a certain value, called the modulus.

Given an integer \(m ≥ 1\), called a modulus, two integers α and β are said to be congruent modulo \(m\), if dividing both integers by \(m\) gives the same remainder. It also means that \(m\) can divide their difference; that is, there is an integer \(k\) such that: $$ α - β = k m$$

Congruent integers can be represented like this: [α ≡ β (mod m)]. Examples: [11 ≡ 20 (mod 3)], [16 ≡ 41 (mod 5)] and [17 ≡ 57 (mod 4)].

Prove or disprove that if \(a ≡ b (\bmod m)\) and \(c ≡ d (\bmod m)\), then \(a + c ≡ b + d (\bmod m)\).
Prove or disprove that if \(a ≡ b (\bmod m)\) and \(c ≡ d (\bmod m)\), then \(ac ≡ bd (\bmod m)\).
Prove or disprove that if \(a ≡ b (\bmod m)\), \(c ≡ d (\bmod m)\), \(c|a\) and \(d|b\), then \(a/c ≡ b/d (\bmod m)\).
Prove or disprove that if \(a ≡ b (\bmod m)\) and \(n|m\), then \(a ≡ b (\bmod nm)\).
Prove or disprove that if \(c\) is an integer and \(a ≡ b (\bmod m)\), then \(ca ≡ cb (\bmod cm)\).
Prove or disprove that if \(d|a\), \(d|b\), \(d|m\) and \(a ≡ b mod m\), then (a/d ≡ b/d \bmod m/d).
Prove or disprove that if \(a ≡ b \bmod m\), then \((b, m) = (a, m)\).
Prove or disprove that if \((ca ≡ cb \bmod m)\) if and only if \((a ≡ b \bmod m/(c, m))\).
Prove or disprove that if \(c\) is an odd integer, then \((c^2 ≡ 1 \bmod 4)\) and \((c^2 ≡ 1 mod 8)\).
Prove or disprove that if \(n\) is a positve integer and \((n ≡ 3 \bmod 4)\), then n cannot be written as a sum of two square integers.
Prove or disprove that if \((b ≡ 1 \bmod m)\), \((b ≡ 1 \bmod n)\) and \(\gcd(m, n) = 1\), then \((b ≡ 1 \bmod mn)\).
Prove or disprove that if n is odd and (3 ∤ n), then \((n^2 ≡ 1 \bmod 24)\).
